content: oh hey guys Adam Scottie here nice to have you with me on the DMS craft short
tip I had a interesting episode for you today I guess I always say that but hey
they're all interesting to me what I'm going to do today is show you how to do
texture on a tile without using the texture paint I had a viewer panorama
freak say to me how expensive it was for him to get the texture paint in Europe
and I never really thought about that but I wanted to
I had a technique to do this but I I do the texture paint because it's quicker
it's quicker and it kind of gives a plastic coat to the tiles and makes them
less a little sturdier but you can do it another another way it's a cheaper way
but it takes longer there's more effort involved in doing the tiles so I wanted
to show this one to go out to panorama freak I want I want to show you this
technique how to do the tiles without the spray texture paint the the paint
was just a debilitating price just a crazy price actually for this person and
I didn't want you know that my craft is about cheap you know doing it on the
cheap so it kind of defeats the purpose if you know the can of paint is 40 some
blocks you know it defeats the purpose of the cheap so what I want to do is do
this episode today and I'm going to show you how to do the tiles with just
acrylic craft paint and without using the texture paint so let's go to the
table I'll show you that now here is my standard dungeon tile you can
see that I've just got a rectangular room with the walls down in the doorway
now I'm going to apply the paint so what I'm gonna do is I'm going to use a
sponge so let me grab my sponge so here's my sponge and I've wet it so it's
damp but it's not soaking wet so I've I've wet it and squeezed all the water
out so it's flexible but it's not super wet so now what I'm going to do is I
will grab my gray paint and my brush use a wide brush and I'll start applying the
gray to the sponge now I could just dip it in the grey but I think it'll easier
to do it this way and you get it all over the sponge so now I will move my
plate out of the way and then you can just start dabbing the tile and see
that's how that's adding a really nice stony texture to that tile
so yeah that's going they go back over some of the other areas get the corners
so now I'm going to put some more paint on there start to
now remember when you're done with this you're going to want to wash out the
sponge because the paint will dry and ruin the sponge if you want to use it
again so make sure you do that so now we've got the first coat on there and
what I'm going to do is I'm going to let that dry and then I'm going to add a
lighter coat to give some more variation to the tile itself so we'll let that dry
and wash out our sponge and then we'll come back for the next step
so this was quick just drive within minutes and now I'm back with the the
second coat I'm gonna do a lighter gray and I just rushed that on the the sponge
like I did with the darker color so now I'll start just applying it to the title
so you're getting in a lighter lighter areas and then you can do the edge
okay so now I've got that so what I'm gonna do is I'm just going to take my
brush and kind of dip it into the paint a little bit I'm just going to do a
little little bit like that just add some more variation so now we'll let
that dry and we'll move on to the next step
now the good thing with this technique is it's a lot cheaper than the spray
paint the bad thing is it doesn't give it kind of a hard shell that the other
texture paint does also it's much more time consuming than the texture paint
but if you're on a budget and you have the time this is a great method to do
now I'm going to kind of finish out the tile add some more detail like I
normally do so I'm going to use my brush get some black very watered-down black
and then go around the edges it's better to put a to light than too too dark
because you can always you can always add some dark to it but you just it's a
lot harder to add there there we go okay now I want to add
a little a few little scuffs and stuff this is gonna be a an older dungeon and
that kind of thing not a new castle or anything so when I had some little
scuffs and just using the tips of the brush just to get some little scuff you
can also remember this looks kind of glassy now but it will it'll dart it'll
lighten somewhat or it won't be glossy because it'll dry there you got some
nice texture on that so I'm gonna let that dry for a sec and
then I'll do a little little little finish up here
so that just dried within minutes so check that out now I'm going to do a
little extra detail I'm gonna do the edging so it kind of pops out so I'm
using my light gray just getting it on my chisel brush and I'm just pulling on
the edge there this is what helps give the tile some dimensionality gives the
illusion that the walls are taller than they actually are the shadow and the
highlight and you can even use smaller scopes if you want but there we go so
we've got a finished tile didn't use any texture paint on it but gave it a easy
way to give it the texture just use the sponge and paint the gray on it
dab it on then dab the lighter and then just add some details with a brush and
you're good to go so like I say this technique will take longer than the
texture paint and if you spray it it kind of gives it like a plastic coat
that makes it a little a little more sturdy this is still fine though so this
is that you can do this instead but yeah for those people who are looking for a
cheaper way to do it or just don't have access to the texture paint this is a
great substitute for doing these kind of dungeon tiles and also keep in mind that
if you do the dirt tunnels like I have shown before that I have done some of
those you can just use the brown so use a brown paint the tile black use a brown
the dark Browns first and then use a lighter brown on top of it and you'll
get that same kind of texture look so there we go and thanks for joining me on
short tip
